topic.name: Information Literacy
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Information Literacy in Computing & Digital Technologies

objectives.objective_text: Identify a fact vs. a story.
Recall that not everything on the internet is true.
Name a teacher or parent as a helper.
Recall that videos can be changed.
Observe a cartoon mixed with real life.
Recall that copying a friend is cheating.
Ask permission to use a picture.
Summarize what Copyright means (right to copy).
Summarize the 5 Ws (Who, What, Where, When, Why).
Explain why we check the date of an article.
Defend the pursuit of objective truth.
Explain why people spread fake news (money/attention).
Check a fact on a checking site.
Explain the danger of echo chambers.
Defend the biblical command against false witness.
Explain why we use quotation marks.
Paraphrase a sentence (write in own words).
Defend the value of original thought.
Speak a question to a device.
Explain using quotes for exact phrases.
Filter image searches by color or type.
Explain how search engines crawl the web.
Defend the need for diverse information sources.
Analyze the four factors of Fair Use.
Compare a news site with a blog.
Analyze the CRAAP test (Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, Purpose).
Analyze the difference between Misinformation (mistake) and Disinformation (on purpose).
Connect confirmation bias to spreading lies.
Analyze the consequences of academic dishonesty.
Evaluate the ethics of AI training on copyrighted art.
Evaluate the funding/ownership of media outlets.
Evaluate the societal impact of the post-truth era.
Evaluate the line between collaboration and collusion.
Construct a project using legally sourced assets.
Construct an annotated bibliography assessing sources.
Construct a verification workflow for viral content.
Synthesize media literacy with technological awareness.
Construct complex search queries for research.
